qas.question: What is one type of configuration in which a capacitor may have its connecting leads organized?
What is another type of configuration in which a capacitor may have its connecting leads arranged?
Which type of configuration is often manufactured with the leads parallel to the body of the capacitor?
How are the leads of an axially configured capacitor arranged?
How could radial leads be more correctly described?
What is one type of configuration in which a capacitor not have its connecting leads organized?
What is another type of configuration in which a capacitor will never have its connecting leads arranged?
Which type of configuration is never manufactured with the leads parallel to the body of the capacitor?
How are the leads of an axially configured capacitor not arranged?
How could radial leads be less correctly described?

context: Capacitors may have their connecting leads arranged in many configurations, for example <a0_0><b5_0>axially<b5_0/><a0_0/> or <a1_0><b6_0>radially<b6_0/><a1_0/>. "Axial" means that the leads are <a3_0><b8_0>on a common axis<b8_0/><a3_0/>, typically the axis of the capacitor's cylindrical body – the leads extend from opposite ends. <a2_0><b7_0>Radial<b7_0/><a2_0/> leads might more accurately be referred to <a4_0>as <b9_0>tandem<b9_0/><a4_0/>; they are rarely actually aligned along radii of the body's circle, so the term is inexact, although universal. The leads (until bent) are usually in planes parallel to that of the flat body of the capacitor, and extend in the same direction; they are often parallel as manufactured.
